description:
Aspergillus piperis CBS 112811 is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. This species was isolated from black pepper (Piper nigrum) and was first described in the scientific literature.

Aspergillus piperis is a haploid, asexual fungus that reproduces through the formation of asexual spores called conidia. The colonies of this species typically appear greenish-gray to olive-green in color and have a velvety or powdery texture. Microscopically, the fungus produces conidiophores (specialized structures that bear the conidia) that are smooth-walled and terminate in a globose vesicle.

This species is known to produce various secondary metabolites, including some that may have potential pharmaceutical or industrial applications. However, further research is needed to fully characterize its biology, ecology, and potential uses.

It is important to note that some Aspergillus species can be opportunistic pathogens, and proper precautions should be taken when handling or studying these fungi.
